title: Titanic
description:
The **RMS Titanic** was a British passenger liner that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean on April 15, 1912.

### Facts:
- Maiden voyage: 10 April 1912
- Passengers: 2,224
- Casualties: 1,517

The wreck was discovered in 1985 and lies at a depth of about 12,500 feet.

title: Sierra Madre
description:
# Sierra Madre (USS Sierra Madre)

The **USS Sierra Madre (AD-18)** was a United States Navy ship that played a pivotal role during and after World War II. Built in the early 1940s, it was originally a **destroyer tender** designed to provide maintenance and support for naval destroyers and smaller ships.

### Key Facts:
- **Launched**: 1943
- **Type**: Destroyer tender
- **Length**: 531 feet (162 meters)
- **Service**: 1944–1960 (U.S. Navy), later transferred to the Philippines

### Sinking Incident:
The **USS Sierra Madre** was decommissioned and sold to the Philippines, where it was renamed **BRP Sierra Madre**. In 1999, the Philippine Navy intentionally grounded the vessel at **Second Thomas Shoal**, located at approximately 9° 47′ 27.4″ N, 115° 51′ 23.7″ E, in the South China Sea. The grounding was a strategic move to assert territorial claims in the area.

Over the years, the ship has deteriorated due to natural elements, but it remains a significant symbol of the ongoing territorial dispute in the region.

### Current Status:
The **BRP Sierra Madre** is still stationed at **Second Thomas Shoal**, serving as a military outpost and a reminder of the geopolitical tensions in the South China Sea.

title: Lepanto
description:
🛳️ Ship Biography: Deneb / Pireas / Lepanto
📌 Vessel Overview

IMO Number: 5088564

Former Names:

Deneb (1962–1969)

Pireas (1969–1980s)

Lepanto (1980s–2000s)

Type: General Cargo Ship

Gross Tonnage: 1,597 tons

Length Overall: 86 meters

Beam: 12.36 meters

Draught: 5.05 meters

Builder: Falkenbergs Varv AB, Falkenberg, Sweden

Year Built: 1962

Flag: Netherlands (initially), later various flags over its service life

Status: Decommissioned, wrecked at Cemitério de Navios, Luanda, Angola

🧭 Career Highlights

1962: Launched as Deneb by Van Nievelt, Goudriaan & Co's Stoomvaart-Maatschappij N.V., Rotterdam, Netherlands.

1969: Renamed Pireas under Greek ownership, continuing as a general cargo vessel.

1980s–2000s: Operated under the name Lepanto, with various owners and managers.

2000s: Eventually decommissioned and abandoned.

⚓ Final Resting Place: Cemitério de Navios

The ship's final voyage ended at the Cemitério de Navios, also known as the Ship Cemetery, located near São Tiago Beach, Luanda, Angola. This area is renowned for its collection of abandoned ships, some of which are close enough to the shore that they can be reached at low tide. The site has become a poignant symbol of maritime history and the passage of time.

🧩 Fascination and Legacy

The story of this vessel is a testament to the transient nature of maritime commerce and the enduring presence of history in unexpected places. Its journey from a bustling cargo ship to a silent sentinel in the sands of Angola invites reflection on the many stories held within the hulls of ships that once sailed the seas.
